text: good point that Ewald brought up when we were chatting about motors/sound: super cool for those watching, potentially much less cool for those on the other side of the wall who are trying to concentrate. iâ€™m sure its an obstacle that could probably be overcome through some clever engineering.
valid point. I think the kind of sound we're talking about would be pretty easy to control/block
there's a really expensive type of sheetrock called quiet rock
we could sheath the back side of the wall with that
quiet rock is such a cool name
or have the robot spider arm take turns moving when no one is watching
or not move at all

In general - i think we just need to be aware of sound. Not extremely important at this point, but is a design parameter for the entire project. I'm certain there's going to be solves for whatever we end up proposing
please bring seinfeld back
you all made that bed yesterday by making fun of my face
:point_up_2:
that icon is terrifying
i'm embracing my true self
/giphy sad clown
:jary:

<!channel>: Hey Team! Wanted to give you all an update after our check in call. It went very well, and in talking about calendar we agreed to extend the current Concept Diligence Phase to a few days past our visits to the office 10/6-10/7. So this means we now have three weeks to get our ideas on paper and get to a doc that outlines what we all agree we're setting out to do.
awesome
It also means we'll likely kick up some engineering conversations in this time so we can get ahead of those discussions, best practices, etc.

Lastly, we'll have an opportunity before we visit to connect with Linda so she can walk us through her data insights , and so we can ask any questions. I'm thinking it would be good to do this some time next week, so let's keep chatting as we move forward and find a time in our process that makes sense for that.

text: <@U02F9CXTL> found this and i love how it is first and foremost an aesthetically beautiful object. The data display is a really amazing feature but not at all necessary to appreciate it. <https://vimeo.com/82566884>

attachments.title: CSIS Global Data Chandelier
attachments.text:
The Global Data Chandelier is a custom light fixture commissioned by the Center for Strategic and International Studies for their new headquarters in Washington, DC. CSIS is a bipartisan, nonprofit think tank focused on international policy and issues of global significance.

Sosolimited partnered with Hypersonic Engineering & Design, Plebian Design, and Chris Parlato to design, program, and fabricate this one-of-a-kind chandelier. 425 hanging pendants form a map of the world when viewed from below. This map becomes a low-res display for illustrating global data such as GDP growth rate, renewable water resources, and energy consumption. Each data set is paired with a unique lighting animation. In addition, CSIS can highlight regions of the map that correspond with international developments or events within the building.

We'd like to give special thanks to the team at CSIS, including Dr. John Hamre, Mason Osborne at Jones Lang LaSalle, and Tom Carrado at Hickok Cole for their help in making this chandelier possible.

Collaborators:
<http://hypersonic.cc>
<http://www.plebiandesign.com>
<http://www.parlato.net>
attachments.fallback: Vimeo Video: CSIS Global Data Chandelier

also <!channel> just as a note to the entire team, since we're stretching out the concept diligence phase from 1 week to 3, I need to be cognizant of our hours since those stay the same :simple_smile: so rather than keeping head's down hot and heavy that whole period, let's scale back to half time on the project just for this phase. i've requested resources that way for next week so you should see them reflected on float, but let me know if any questions/concerns/whatever come up and i'm happy to chat about it
